conclusion: To determine the magnitude of the normal force N between the locking tongue D and the locking groove E when the door is in the self-locking state, we need to analyze the forces acting on the latch D.
The spring is compressed by a distance x.

According to Newtonâ€™s third law, there will also be an equal and opposite reaction force that acts on the spring, but for our purposes, the spring force is the one affecting the latch.
There is a frictional force f1 due to the sliding motion along the lower surface of the latch D.
Additionally, there is a frictional force f2 due to the inclined surface of the latch D.
The normal force N acts perpendicular to the surface of the locking groove E.

premise: There is a frictional force f1 due to the sliding motion along the lower surface of the latch D.
conclusion: The frictional force f1 can be resolved into two components: Parallel component (f1_parallel): f1_parallel = f1 cos(theta) and Perpendicular component (f1_perp): f1_perp = f1 sin(theta)

The maximum static friction force F_fm is given by: F_fm = mu F_N
Since the door is in the self-locking state, the total frictional force must balance the spring force in the direction perpendicular to the surface.

Given that the maximum static friction force is the sum of the components of the frictional forces.
conclusion: N = kx + mu f1 sin(theta) + mu f2 sin(theta)

conclusion: N = kx + mu (sin(theta) f1 + sin(theta) f2)
Recognizing that in the case of self-locking, the frictional forces f1 and f2 are such that their combined effect equals the spring force in the perpendicular direction.
